issue.title: Undefined behavior without proper requirements on basic_string constructors

discussion.p: In , I believe tighter requirements should be imposed on basic_string's constructors taking an s argument (or, a behavior should be provided for the undefined cases). These requirements are properly stated in the other members functions taking s arguments (append, assign, insert,...).

blockquote.pre: basic_string(const charT* s, size_type n, const Allocator& a = Allocator());

discussion.p: Relative to N3485, /6 says "Requires: s shall not be a null pointer and n < npos", where it should say: "Requires: s points to an array of at least n elements of charT"

blockquote.pre: basic_string(const charT* s, const Allocator& a = Allocator());

discussion.p: /8 says "Requires: s shall not be a null pointer.", where it should say: "Requires: s points to an array of at least traits::length(s) + 1 elements of charT"
I think that p1 b2 basically requires this already, but the wording is indeed worth improving it.

resolution.p: This wording is relative to N3485.

blockquote.pre: basic_string(const charT* s, size_type n, const Allocator& a = Allocator());

blockquote.p: -6- Requires: s shall not be a null pointer and n < npospoints to an array of at least n elements of charT.

blockquote.pre: basic_string(const charT* s, const Allocator& a = Allocator());

blockquote.p: -8- Requires: s shall not be a null pointerpoints to an array of at least traits::length(s) + 1 elements of charT.
